document.title: Pennsylvania Assessment Anchors and Eligible Content

1B25C8BF27B948918CD190E495830910.description:
Compare and contrast characteristics of celestial bodies found in the solar
system (e.g., moons, asteroids, comets, meteors, inner and outer planets).

4895ACCDB77B4D16BA305D1102083032.description:
Describe the role of gravity as the force that governs the movement of
the solar system and universe.

54F22BC501154264943CA7CA1F1B1B34.description:
Describe patterns of earth’s movements (i.e., rotation and
revolution) in relation to the moon and sun (i.e., phases, eclipses, and tides)

9F7E8E9F1AFE4867BD60061F12326A15.description: Explain the relationships between and among the objects of our solar system.

7DBEC6F0E319491EAEB579E70995F761.description: Composition and Structure of the Universe

4340DA5C3E1C44DCB2987172D42C07C8.description:
Identify how cloud types, wind directions, and barometric pressure
changes are associated with weather patterns in different regions of the country.

F61D3891688E4E22B5741A2DEE87B203.description:
Identify how global patterns of atmospheric movement influence
regional weather and climate.

9CAEC6BA5FB24FF7A4531D47E9F34F0D.description:
Explain the impact of water systems on the local weather or the climate of
a region (e.g., lake effect snow, land/ocean breezes).

F53654F31EC446CAA4CD52C054FDBED0.description:
Explain how pressure, temperature, moisture, and wind are used to describe
atmospheric conditions that affect regional weather or climate.

A6F9801399134D0D8AFB43B3E578EFA7.description:
Identify the physical characteristics of a stream and how these
characteristics determine the types of organisms found within the stream environment (e.g., biological diversity, water quality, flow rate, tributaries, surrounding watershed).

D409973A2EDD4129A46EC5B24BB805BC.description:
Distinguish among different water systems (e.g., wetland systems,
ocean systems, river systems, watersheds) and describe their relationships to each other as well as to landforms.

0DC787A8C4274247A1A59D3A4256EFF9.description:
Compare and contrast characteristics of freshwater and saltwater systems
on the basis of their physical characteristics (i.e., composition, density, and electrical conductivity) and their use as natural resources.

2CDEE0F0EFA24A56A6ED88ED01A2708E.description:
Describe the water cycle and the physical processes on which it
depends (i.e., evaporation, condensation, precipitation, transpiration, runoff, infiltration, energy inputs, and phase changes).

F7C6DEA1FFB44C9BBC285AAA36A6F177.description:
Describe characteristic features of Earth’s water systems or their impact on
resources.

BE894A0A0A4A42C7B98A17E3AF276313.description:
Describe potential impacts of human- made processes (e.g., manufacturing,
agriculture, transportation, mining) on Earth’s resources, both nonliving (i.e., air, water, or earth materials) and living (i.e., plants and animals).

C295CB239D5D41D2858784CE8AA53485.description:
Describe a product’s transformation process from production to
consumption (e.g., prospecting, propagating, growing, maintaining, adapting, treating, converting, distributing, disposing) and explain the process’s potential impact on Earth’s resources.

49A897C0CF974E0C8CC3ECC7FFACA696.description:
Describe the potential impact of human- made processes on changes to Earth’s
resources and how they affect everyday life.

6E5F600777E0450F8AD4349068851970.description:
Explain how fossils provide evidence about plants and animals that once
lived throughout Pennsylvania’s history (e.g., fossils provide evidence of different environments).

0EFAD1A457ED42A1B3F04F6EB7D4EB6C.description:
Identify soil types (i.e., humus, topsoil, subsoil, loam, loess, and parent
material) and their characteristics (i.e., particle size, porosity, and permeability) found in different biomes and in Pennsylvania, and explain how they formed.

80BBC1D614174AC08EB03D1B836AB013.description:
Describe natural processes that change Earth’s surface (e.g.,
landslides, volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, mountain building, new land being formed, weathering, erosion, sedimentation, soil formation).

B7B72121CFA84EE1935B5882A15AEEF5.description:
Explain the rock cycle as changes in the solid earth and rock types
(igneous – granite, basalt, obsidian, pumice; sedimentary – limestone, sandstone, shale, coal; and metamorphic – slate, quartzite, marble, gneiss).

0EE812E714E3428AAF18F8851CFE874B.description:
Describe constructive and destructive natural processes that form different
geologic structures and resources.

DA22123F26624900A32532617146FB4E.description: Earth Features and Processes that Change Earth and Its Resources

5E4DC6178346440484B659D6FFDEAB44.description:
Explain that mechanical advantage helps to do work (physics) by either
changing a force or changing the direction of the applied force (e.g., simple machines, hydraulic systems).

A838A8139DDB460A9FF9D0A2C15776CC.description: Distinguish between kinetic and potential energy.

412D7227582E44DD86D47E595D034E53.description:
Describe forces acting on objects (e.g., friction, gravity, balanced versus
unbalanced).

D3721753EDD341A88A09A28BB71AA3DA.description:
Describe the effect of multiple forces on the movement, speed, or direction of an
object.

3D66AA4EE61649F8AECF6AC2CD3BE7DD.description:
Describe the waste (i.e., kind and quantity) derived from the use of
renewable and nonrenewable resources and their potential impact on the environment.

C049E5B7818A42949E02FB6F07DA6CC1.description:
Compare the time span of renewability for fossil fuels and the
time span of renewability for alternative fuels.

EA74F3DB1A474B9E878C25EB69F65343.description:
Describe the Sun as the major source of energy that impacts the
environment.

9B6F862597024C6FA32C35E8B440C573.description:
Compare the environmental impact of different energy sources chosen to
support human endeavors.

FC12A048CF0E41ACB10D3262A296C152.description:
Describe how one form of energy (e.g., electrical, mechanical, chemical,
light, sound, nuclear) can be converted into a different form of energy.

1E47ED956F8041EFBF1726D5A42A00E2.description:
Explain how energy is transferred from one place to another through
convection, conduction, or radiation.

2625FC949AC240C6AE757B110D5F46B3.description:
Distinguish among forms of energy (e.g., electrical, mechanical, chemical,
light, sound, nuclear) and sources of energy (i.e., renewable and nonrenewable energy)

A3C7DB89B3C441DAB951FAFDEE15C4ED.description: Describe energy sources, transfer of energy, or conversion of energy.

9932A519E7D7418CA282F775C0DBA01E.description: Forms, Sources, Conversion, and Transfer of Energy

248285DB163C47EFBA755179DF0B57A1.description:
Identify and describe reactants and products of simple chemical
reactions.

17557A7D723D4A69B37B937CB38C549E.description:
Use characteristic physical or chemical properties to distinguish one substance from another (e.g., density,
thermal expansion/contraction, freezing/melting points, streak test).

61956E26532F4223A9F427E260818B5B.description: Explain the differences among elements, compounds, and mixtures.

39F0C2E86CC3456C8E681ABEEBC58889.description:
Explain concepts about the structure and properties (physical and chemical)
of matter.

E6374369B909492F8605A8C8D30CEABD.description: Structure, Properties, and Interaction of Matter and Energy

5B60667A14964A7BA1A0F3C6368E6469.description:
Explain the long-term effects of using integrated pest management (e.g.,
herbicides, natural predators, biogenetics) on the environment.

9B570E61B3934D71B6DECBF85422D400.description:
Describe how waste management affects the environment (e.g., recycling,
composting, landfills, incineration, sewage treatment).

00609758ABEA45BDA6B9A8407B0C720E.description:
Explain how renewable and nonrenewable resources provide for
human needs (i.e., energy, food, water, clothing, and shelter).

57E3BF8738B44ED5B6404A3FFF4B94E5.description:
Explain how human activities may affect local, regional, and global
environments.

076F07831A794FF8937EE252CBB5A14A.description:
Explain how renewable and non- renewable resources provide for
human needs or how these needs impact the environment.

A6040C5AE3CD4C67AC0F8FE7BFC7F173.description:
Describe the response of organisms to environmental changes (e.g., changes
in climate, hibernation, migration, coloration) and how those changes affect survival.

65ABBDCF1FBD4341A6D28419DDCED167.description:
Use evidence to explain how diversity affects the ecological integrity of natural
systems.

8123C1854327469F94888712C12F88EE.description:
Use evidence to explain factors that affect changes in populations (e.g.,
deforestation, disease, land use, natural disaster, invasive species).

DAAE0C1CEE7F43249C7852C708E17750.description: Identify evidence of change to infer and explain the ways different variables may affect change in natural or human-made systems.

1AF055A06028463997CE18C9EC9D916D.description:
Explain relationships among organisms (e.g., producers/consumers,
predator/prey) in an ecosystem.

E7E09026CA3A4ADAAE292E5A979B48AE.description:
Identify major biomes and describe abiotic and biotic components (e.g.,
abiotic: different soil types, air, water sunlight; biotic: soil microbes, decomposers).

335D7B593DE14DC197CAEBB1E539CC46.description:
Explain the flow of energy through an ecosystem (e.g., food chains, food
webs).

521A916AAD8649B6809CEB05ABEA78F4.description:
Explain the relationships among and between organisms in different
ecosystems and their abiotic and biotic components.

A2C6A0617E894CD3A1FFB852C7A1179F.description:
Recognize that the gene is the basic unit of inheritance, that there are
dominant and recessive genes, and that traits are inherited.

72CD20C9962A40A8A13086D95AF27C40.description: Identify and explain differences between inherited and acquired traits.

89500807A2A443B180128924237275C9.description: Explain how a set of genetic instructions determines inherited traits of organisms.

68C856EDC6CD4B8F89FCC3AC219241AE.description:
Explain that adaptations are developed over long periods of time
and are passed from one generation to another.

8CFEA3D3CE174F0CBF56E9EFF21281D1.description:
Describe how selective breeding or biotechnology can change the genetic
makeup of organisms.

3D30DF065D02460FAC43A816CE332345.description:
Explain that mutations can alter a gene and are the original source of
new variations.

5E92385AD02B468E8A9C2882792F9DA8.description:
Explain how different adaptations in individuals of the same species may
affect survivability or reproduction success.

D119F7293F8A4442906F6B1CAA7929BF.description:
Explain how inherited structures or behaviors help organisms survive and
reproduce in different environments.

D0F12BD5DF704DD48318E8316D92B86B.description: Explain the basic concepts of natural selection.

BFD22A175E66470AAB24A7BF237B8DBE.description:
Identify the levels of organization from cell to organism and describe how
specific structures (parts), which underlie larger systems, enable the system to function as a whole.

99C1B091CE234BB8BE214E56B5AE04AD.description:
Apply knowledge of characteristic structures to identify or categorize
organisms (i.e., plants, animals, fungi, bacteria, and protista).

37C3A884315344A08DEAD38E23DA00FF.description:
Compare similarities and differences in internal structures of organisms
(e.g., invertebrate/vertebrate, vascular/nonvascular, single- celled/multi-celled) and external structures (e.g., appendages, body segments, type of covering, size, shape).

CE84371B9F214210AA3390B9E010FDEA.description:
Describe the structures of living things that help them function effectively in
specific ways (e.g., adaptations, characteristics).

39D295C68FF94A9FBB05F04680593C3E.description:
Describe and compare structural and functional similarities and differences
that characterize diverse living things.

36BD2E61C67041EF84AD0512BAA85402.description:
Describe repeating structure patterns in nature (e.g., veins in a leaf, tree
rings, crystals, water waves) or periodic patterns (e.g., daily, monthly, annually).

9DD9A22C9D0F4FF8BE3B2FDF1B077697.description:
Identify and describe patterns as repeated processes or recurring
elements in human-made systems (e.g., trusses, hub-and-spoke system in communications and transportation systems, feedback controls in regulated systems).

96973FACE64B4E1CBC755DCB36481D79.description:
Describe repeated processes or recurring elements in natural, scientific,
and technological patterns.

4F4FA2ABBAFB4800B9E1BB3F945E5DDF.description:
Given a model showing simple cause- and-effect relationships in a natural
system, predict results that can be used to test the assumptions in the model (e.g., photosynthesis, water cycle, diffusion, infiltration).

C364EEB9F49640E3947BE28BEAD79D6F.description:
Describe how engineers use models to develop new and improved
technologies to solve problems.

47A36E270F2C49FC8D491BFBEA2A8201.description:
Describe how scientists use models to explore relationships in natural
systems (e.g., an ecosystem, river system, the solar system).

FF65973BC4E645B3A3AB00845625ABE8.description:
Apply knowledge of models to make predictions, draw inferences, or explain
technological concepts.

E9F118C6DB16422CB82737E25AA6F4F0.description:
Explain how components of natural and human-made systems play
different roles in a working system.

009D3839589D4FF88FF0A66B916710AB.description:
Distinguish between open loop (e.g., energy flow, food web) and closed
loop (e.g., materials in the nitrogen and carbon cycles, closed-switch) systems.

AE74DBCFD6E946DE840BA8EDB631FBD5.description:
Distinguish among system inputs, system processes, system outputs,
and feedback (e.g., physical, ecological, biological, informational).

4D6610D45EBB41D6BF4001EB7E59CE4F.description:
Explain the concept of order in a system [e.g., (first to last:
manufacturing steps, trophic levels); (simple to complex: cell, tissue, organ, organ system)].

F3CBB4BBD63A4E398999045148904665.description:
Describe a system (e.g., watershed, circulatory system, heating system,
agricultural system) as a group of related parts with specific roles that work together to achieve an observed result.

F91DFAF3902A40E4818CFB8ECB54BBBB.description:
Explain the parts of a simple system, their roles, and their relationships to the
system as a whole.

2ECEC43DEB024E858D6AFFD8E9A1A175.description:
Describe ways technology (e.g., microscope, telescope, micrometer, hydraulics, barometer) extends and
enhances human abilities for specific purposes.

B8CBA92B9FC84D91BE4156DF4B24BC08.description:
Apply appropriate measurement systems (e.g., time, mass, distance,
volume, temperature) to record and interpret observations under varying conditions.

E9706C5E2DD3495EBD95395CEF7D0BFB.description:
Describe the appropriate use of instruments and scales to accurately
and safely measure time, mass, distance, volume, or temperature under a variety of conditions.

4BC31F0805FF4E528FC23F5FE3C91CAA.description:
Apply appropriate instruments for a specific purpose and describe the
information the instrument can provide.

DA97B35B3346405597F161098F4431AA.description:
Identify a design flaw in a simple technological system and devise
possible working solutions.

016F3BD9A9E94F89B3257DC33077CBD1.description:
Use evidence from investigations to clearly communicate and support
conclusions.

ECB298F5FCA34BBF902FDAB8CC911774.description:
Interpret data/observations; develop relationships among variables based
on data/observations to design models as solutions.

DBFEBB7FD583478898B7C2C39ACA61C7.description:
Design a controlled experiment by specifying how the independent
variables will be manipulated, how the dependent variable will be measured, and which variables will be held constant.

EB8ECCD6B5374BC1B9AC46F2B7807252.description:
Use space/time relationships, define concepts operationally, raise testable
questions, or formulate hypotheses.

3F0000E3C20B48CABB1C67A4402D27C5.description:
Use evidence, observations, or a variety of scales (e.g., mass,
distance, volume, temperature) to describe relationships.

8CF5A1B63A834B75A20E1EAEFA83CE1D.description:
Apply knowledge of scientific investigation or technological design in
different contexts to make inferences to solve problems.

D7F03EE88D5A47D4B4ECBE01CE09DA94.description: Processes, Procedures, and Tools of Scientific Investigations

C4744B318E654F5B851609EB7C70E3E3.description:
Given a scenario, explain how a dynamically changing environment
provides for the sustainability of living systems.

B44C2281133740F9935116785B9AC745.description:
Examine systems changing over time, identifying the possible variables
causing this change, and drawing inferences about how these variables affect this change.

C0E23754D7D1403E935944EFFAAD3A20.description:
Use evidence, observations, or explanations to make inferences
about change in systems over time (e.g., carrying capacity, succession, population dynamics, loss of mass in chemical reactions, indicator fossils in geologic time scale) and the variables affecting these changes.

3B104C17150F400CB0EA65B744250CAA.description:
Use ratio to describe change (e.g., percents, parts per million, grams per
cubic centimeter, mechanical advantage).

810963DD6CC14F71B91154727DE53EE3.description:
Identify and analyze evidence that certain variables may have caused
measurable changes in natural or human-made systems.

ED51CE5B87CE4BC4848122D32E7B794C.description:
Explain society’s standard of living in terms of technological advancements and how these advancements impact
on agriculture (e.g., transportation, processing, production, storage).

B43A84DF13AD412B9DB098637E953B00.description:
Describe fundamental scientific or technological concepts that could
solve practical problems (e.g., Newton’s laws of motion, Mendelian genetics).

946C01BFD0154C4BB54970D2C58F1521.description:
Identify environmental issues and explain their potential long-term
health effects (e.g., pollution, pest controls, vaccinations).

6D14EDDB4D0F404F92BD81711898C139.description:
Describe the positive and negative, intended and unintended, effects of
specific scientific results or technological developments (e.g., air/space travel, genetic engineering, nuclear fission/fusion, artificial intelligence, lasers, organ transplants).

B4338D932A284FF6AF51715D2DFF86D0.description:
Identify and explain the impacts of applying scientific, environmental, or
technological knowledge to address solutions to practical problems.

247608C40DC849C1A77EAF1A03934495.description:
Develop descriptions, explanations, predictions, and models using
evidence.

1722C88D525A44C4A3C2B0196D80FABC.description:
Use evidence, such as observations or experimental results, to support
inferences about a relationship.

64C9A08636F141A6B4C20F03C18A3AEE.description:
Explain how certain questions can be answered through scientific inquiry
and/or technological design.

A4A4E29039B34308BF414E71E8B3D3C3.description:
Distinguish between a scientific theory and an opinion, explaining how a
theory is supported with evidence, or how new data/information may change existing theories and practices.

C4B7A123D5954463A9CB1B8B4C2D804B.description:
Explain, interpret, and apply scientific, environmental, or technological
knowledge presented in a variety of formats (e.g., visuals, scenarios, graphs).
